Award.AwardTitle: Midwest Noyce Regional Conference in 2010 and 2011

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis (IUPUI) is planning and implementing two annual conferences for faculty and students from Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship program sites located in the Midwestern region of the United States. The conferences are focused on the following primary goals: 1) to provide professional development to meet the needs of the Noyce Scholars/Teachers who will be or are working in "high need" rural and urban schools and districts; 2) to create a forum for sharing best practices and effective strategies for such Noyce program management issues as scholar recruitment, early career mentoring, evidence-based design of program assessment, and partnership building between college and university Noyce programs and school districts; 3) to provide a network of peer support to Noyce Teacher Scholarship project personnel and Noyce Scholars/Fellows throughout the states in the Midwest; and 4) to establish post-conference mechanisms for networking, regular communication, and future conference planning. In a broader sense, by offering the Noyce Scholars the opportunity to share experiences, expertise, and skills with their peers and colleagues, the conferences and post-conference networking opportunities serve as a platform to elevate the professional identity of the Noyce Scholars, and have the potential to become an important factor in their overall satfisfaction and long-term persistence in diverse classrooms and in the teaching profession. For Noyce program personnel, the conferences offer a comfortable forum for sharing best practices in program management, and opportunities for discussion about effective pathways to prepare and develop excellent STEM teacher scholars who commit to teaching diverse students in high needs classrooms throughout the Midwest.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The principal investigator of the project, Dr. Kim S. Nguyen and her collaborators Drs. K. Marrs, J. Staver, and S. Kastberg received the award in the amount of $352,437 to organize the Midwest Noyce Regional Conference for 2010 and 2011. The team was able to maximize the available fund to host three conferences (2010, 2011, and 2012) on the campus of Indiana University Purdue University Indianapolis. Conference participants were representatives of 48 active, National Science Foundation funded Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship awards in 15 states in the Midwest: AR, IA, ID, IL, IN, KS, KY, MI, MN, MO, ND, OH, SD, WI, and WV. The award fund supported the attendance of teams of 4 participants from each project that included the project PI and three Noyce Scholars or Noyce Fellows. There were 359 conference participants attending the three Midwest Noyce Regional Conferences.

The conference agendas were constructed around a specific theme each year:

  • 2010 Preparing Excellent STEM Teachers for Urban and Rural High-need Schools.
  • 2011 Developing Noyce Scholars for Excellent STEM Teaching at Urban and Rural High-need Classrooms.
  • 2012 Common Core, NGSS and Digital Learners: STEM Teaching at the Crossroads.

The conference assessment annual reports confirmed that the conferences were effectively managed and the impacts were sustainable. The annual conference evaluation was constructed around the three ojective of this project: 1) Creating networks of peer support for Noyce projects' PIs across the Midwest, 2) Providing professional development for and building networks of support to Noyce Scholars and Fellows, 30 Sharing best practices on scholar recruitment, mentoring, induction support and project management. The conference agendas, photos, and conference proceedings were published and available for free downloading from the conference website  http://noyceconferenceindy.org .

One of the significant outcomes of this project is the establishment of sustainable networks of project personnel of the Noyce projects in the Midwest. Dr. Nguyen will continue the work of building Noyce communities of practices as she serves as a CoPI on the new Midwest Noyce Conference grant for 2014 and 2015. The project entitled "Midwest Regional Robert Noyce Connections 2014-2015: Building Communities of Practice" will strengthen the outcomes achieved by this award.
